sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message: is it possible CERT_MODE_OPENSTACK is not at index 0 (which appears to be the case for loop above); then it appears that CERT_MODE_OPENSTACK will not be handled.

> is it possible CERT_MODE_OPENSTACK is not at index 0 (which appears
 > to be the case for loop above); then it appears that
 > CERT_MODE_OPENSTACK will not be handled.

An intermediate CA signed server cert will contain more than one certificates. The order of the certificates in the cert file is significant, the first one should be the actual server certifcate (the leaf), followed by the intermediate CA certificates that signs the preceding ones.

So only the first one (the actual server certificate) will (and should) has DN/SAN that matches the hostname (the other certs are intermediate CA certs). That's why only index=0 is checked.

Also as you can see in the above loop, if the first cert is a CA cert (which it shouldn't), the API will return error to caller.

The mode is independent from the cert loop. I think it will be more clear to move the if mode conditions outside the for loop. i.e,
if mode in [...]
   for ....

> The mode is independent from the cert loop. I think it will be more
 > clear to move the if mode conditions outside the for loop. i.e,
 > if mode in [...]
 > for ....

No. Each of the certs need to go through some checking, and all of them need to pass self._check_cert-validity(). Some types of certs need extra checking. Otherwise we will end up with multiple loops (each for some types of certs).
if mode in [...] then skip the loop. The condition should be outside the loop.

> if mode in [...] then skip the loop. The condition should be
 > outside the loop.

No. Even for the types of certs in [...], we still need to return one to the caller (the leaf cert). We just skip these intermediate CA certs from the list.
Further more, this is generic code for any types of certs, CA types certs will go through this loop to build a list.

Schema files are stored for major versions only, in your scenario a schema file (1) would be loaded. This is to catch scenarios where the major version is known, but the minor version is outside the range we know. What it does not do is catch unsupported intermediate minor versions (say we support [1.0, 1.1, 2.0] - then 1.2 will pass this check since 1.2 is between 1.0 and 2.0). I can add a comment for that, or look into storing supported major.minor versions explicitly, but that may result in a very long list of supported versions in the future.

I think we should maintain a current major and minor but allow minor values <= current minor. Next independent step load the schema file.

The supported versions stored in the globals are a range, not single minor and major versions. In your example MIN_SCHEMA_VERSION would be 1.0 and MAX_SCHEMA_VERSION would be 1.3, therefore 1.2 would not trigger this as it falls within that range.

As far as unsupported major versions, they are caught above when we try to load the schema for the major version. This is only really to catch major/minor version combinations.

Also, we are continuing to load supported major versions with unknown minor versions but will only process fields known by our latest minor version. This should be OK because if a change in the schema breaks this, we should increment the major version.

Good point, but assume schema_version 1.1 adds new identification method "foo". Then take the following cases:

1) input 1.0, schema 1.1: input will never contain "foo"

2) input 1.1 with "foo", but schema 1.0 as implementation is 1.0. If input contains "foo" then the schema accepts it BUT the implementation cannot handle the "foo" identification method and no other method can be provided in the input along with "foo" (due to min/maxProperties) so the post check fails.

I think in this case it is totally OK to only accept identification methods in the schema that are known by the implementation. So here we can say additionalProperties: false without loosing compatibility as that compatibility is already lost on the implementation level.

Two things here:
One, when using assertEqual, the reference (expected) value should always come first in the list. So it should read "self.assertEqual(hw_tags, ...)"
This makes the error message more readable to understand the expected value vs. the returned value.

Second, this is testing that the tags are in the hm_kwargs list, which is what you set and passed into the create method. You want to test the values in the "hm" object returned by the status GET call to validate they are present in the response.
So, corrected it would read:
self.assertEqual(hw_tags, hm[const.TAGS])

Ok, so I am a little confused, what should I do in this case?

In OpenStack we have a standard of three blocks of import statements:

1. python built in modules
2. modules that are external to this application, but are not included with python.
3. modules that are part of this application.

dateutil is not part of the python built in modules (https://pypi.org/project/python-dateutil/1.4/), so it should be grouped with the modules in the second section.

nova/accelerator/cyborg.py.message:
Is this really the right thing to do? We've got ARQs, and we go to bind them, which fails, and at the end, our ARQs are gone/deleted?

I'm guessing this is baked into bind just because of how things work today, but in terms of this being generally useful in the future, like maybe for a migration, we'd want to just report error and let the caller decide if the right thing to do is delete them, try again, etc.

When we execute bind, the arq record has been created in Cybrog and a Resource Provider map has been made. If instance failed to bind, I think it is necessary to perform the deletion of the occupied resources.

Having this bind operation delete the arq is like having a filesystem move operation delete the source file even if it doesn't have permission to write to the new location. Otherwise it should be called bind_or_delete_arqs_on_failure(), which is a silly single operation to have. If we want to try another host, we should be able to do that, or if the code calling this isn't in a position to try another, then let *it* delete them.

i am currently planning to move the call to _delete_arqs_by_uuid to an exception handeler that catches the AcceleratorRequestOpFailed exception raised below.

for spwan this will have the same behavior but any other code that then uses bind_arqs can choose to either catch the exception and either delete the arqs or perhaps retry the binding.

if nothing handels the error then the binding would be cleaned up when the vm is deleted by the end user.

> if nothing handels the error then the binding would be cleaned up
 > when the vm is deleted by the end user.

How? Th VM deletion path calls delete_arqs_by_instance(), which deletes the ARQs bound to an instance UUID. But, in this path, the ARQs are not yet bound to an instance UUID on the Cyborg side.

In this error path, ARQs have been created but the attempt to bind has failed. So, how will those created ARQs be deleted? There will not be any notification from Cyborg of a bind-completion event. Other clean up paths in Nova call delete_arqs_by_instance(), but the ARQ is not yet bound to an instance, so that won't delete these ARQs either.

In terms of general utility, this call is not idempotent, so one has to be extra careful about potentially calling this multiple times.

we could pull this out of bind i guess and handel it in reponce to the excpeiton that is raised.

cyborg has the ablity to unbind ARQs and then bind them to a new host but currently they dont use the unbound state so sunder wanted to prefer deleting and recreating the ARQs if we were to rechsudle instead of unbind and rebind for spawn.

so ya that expected behavior is being backed in here which is likely not correct i can pull this out and hanel the error at the call site by deleing the bindings and then reraising it.

If you drop the message parameter from the constructor as I suggested then this becomes a lot clearer:

  exception.AcceleratorRequestBindingFailed(msg=err_msg, arqs=arq_uuids)

nova/tests/unit/objects/test_instance.py.message:
This ensures that the _save_extra_generic() gets called for the keypairs, but that's not enough. If you make this change:

 diff --git a/nova/tests/unit/objects/test_instance.py b/nova/tests/unit/objects/test_instance.py
 index c9ccdff959..3d0308b2c0 100644
 --- a/nova/tests/unit/objects/test_instance.py
 +++ b/nova/tests/unit/objects/test_instance.py
 @@ -483,6 +483,8 @@ class _TestInstanceObject(object):
          inst.vm_state = 'meow'
          inst.task_state = 'wuff'
          inst.user_data = 'new'
 +        inst.keypairs = objects.KeyPairList(objects=[
 +            objects.KeyPair(name='foo')])
          save_kwargs.pop('context', None)
          inst.save(**save_kwargs)
          self.assertEqual('newhost', inst.host)

You will see that the keypairs attribute stays dirty after the save() because implicit marking of nested fields as clean isn't always straightforward.

I think the proper thing to do is keep the _save_keypairs() handler, call the generic save handler, and then self.obj_reset_changes('keypairs'). See _save_security_groups() or _save_flavor() for examples.

This makes no sense. You're resetting changes on a thing you want to be save()d. The only reason you're noticing this in the save handler is that you're setting the object on the instance after this, which also tickle's the parent's dirty flag for the object.

If you made this something more realistic, where you modify instance.keypairs (like to add a new one or change the keypairs[0] object) instead of setting it directly on the top-level object, you'd fail your test on L708 because your reset in the instance object doesn't reset the flag on save(). For example:

 inst.keypairs = objects.KeyPairList([])
 inst.keypairs.obj_reset_changes(recurisive=True)
 inst.keypairs.objects.append(objects.KeyPair(name='foo'))
 inst.save()

This is a much more common case of updating keypairs during rebuild, which would leave inst.keypairs dirty, and fail your assertion on L708.

Yeah

  self.assertEqual(0, len(inst.obj_what_changed()))

would be better, or even just

  self.assertEqual(set(), inst.obj_what_changed())

(once again, _why_ didn't Python core choose a different symbol for set notation :'()
This didn't need to be reformatted and just requires reviewers to eye-parse it to confirm that nothing changed.

And these are supposed to be simulating a device only attached to the persistent domain and not the live domain. But this test isn't reflecting a real life scenario as VIR_ERR_INVALID_ARG is raised when the persistent device is not attached when the detach attempt happens.

VIR_ERR_INVALID_ARG or VIR_ERR_DEVICE_MISSING can be raised when the device isn't attached to the persistent / inactive config. I'm not fully sold on this being a valid test anyway but wanted to cover it as the original test_detach_device_with_retry_invalid_argument_no_live was here.

OK, so we have VIR_ERR_OPERATION_FAILED, VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR, and VIR_ERR_DEVICE_MISSING covered here. Do we also need to cover VIR_ERR_INVALID_ARG? (If we aren't discriminating about which error applies to which of live/persistent domain?)

Here we cover VIR_ERR_INVALID_ARG and VIR_ERR_DEVICE_MISSING. Should we also cover VIR_ERR_OPERATION_FAILED and VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR if we're not labeling any errors as only for live or only for persistent?
Same for these two, covering VIR_ERR_INVALID_ARG and VIR_ERR_DEVICE_MISSING. What about VIR_ERR_OPERATION_FAILED and VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR?
None indicates the successful first detach, fake_exc indicates the failing(not found) second detach from live.

OK, so these 3 tests ^ cover the second detach (+1 on the test name change). The second detach can only be for the live detach. The live detach can only be one of:

VIR_ERR_OPERATION_FAILED
VIR_ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR
VIR_ERR_DEVICE_MISSING

the first two of which will be removed once the min is >= 4.1.0.

OK, so the way this test was originally written, the intent was that the detach from persistent fails (and VIR_ERR_INVALID_ARG is the only error code for that). The rest of the error codes are for a failure to detach from live.

It is true though that we do call detach with live + persistent flags and it would be possible for detach from persistent to succeed while detach from live fails in that *single call*. And I think this is what lyarwood is covering here, both cases: detach from persistent fails (VIR_ERR_INVALID_ARG) and then detach from live success OR detach from persistent succeeds and detach from live fails with not found the first time and succeeds the second time. Which means we would substitute each of the 4 error codes here to get the behavior.

This all means that the comments on L343 and L351 and L360 are no longer accurate. It should really say "Detach from persistent *or live* raises not found" since we're covering all the error codes now (which is a good thing).

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
What was an actual problem on the existing 'shared' visibility? Is that security issue?
Happy to see some bug report if we have.

Reasoning for this change is rather user experience than directly security. The problem with the "shared" default visibility is that for new user it indeed looks like a security vulnerability. When new image is created currently the image details shows it as "shared" which spooks users. While the image is not in fact shared with anyone before there is members added to it. This creates very crappy user experience.

My concern is the default value could be changed like a swinging pendulum in the future if we don't have a concrete evidence. And that could hurt users and operators.

BTW isn't it possible to implement this as a config option which option's default value is 'shared' to avoid hurting them for soft changing?

Config option is technically possible to implement, yet it won't happen for two reasons. Our config file is already way north of 3k lines of all kind of crap. Adding pointless config option there will not make operator life any easier. The other problem having this as configurable is inconsistency among deployments. Default values are supposed to be reasonable defaults and making this configurable _and_ leaving the default of that config option to something that has been identified as user experience problem is again not going to help anyone. It also will cause confusion amongs users when they cannot depend on behaviour from the cloud.

You're worried that the default value could be changed by the community and yet you propose a solution for that being easily changeable by the deployer, so please what are you actually concerned about?

Maybe my main concern is it is difficult to see any actual feedback(voice) from operators/users, because I cannot find any bug reports/survey which mention such feedback.

I just wanted to be confident to see "We never change the default value again". Please help me to be confident.

nova/virt/hardware.py.message:
I am aware of some problem existed for code here and in this[1] place.

If I set the 'dedicated_cpus' when 'realtime_cpus' is unset, then the 'pcups' got in place [1] is the CPU number of realtime_cpus, which is less than 'flavor.vcpus'. This is problematic that we request to create a DEDICATED instance, but creates a MIXED instance. I'd like to swap the order of setting 'pcpus' in [1].

     pcpus = dedicated_cpus or realtime_cpus

If it is a dedicated instance, whatever it has any realtime CPU or not, the 'dedicated_cpus' suppress the 'realtime_cpus' and all vCPUs are PCPUs. and the realtime policy will be handled in later by hypervisor driver if it is a realtime instance.

just to note this will run after glance has already started so it would only be picked up if glance auto reload the policy file when its modifed or reads it form disk every time it need to check the policy.

yeah it dynamic load here. oslo policy load_rules() on every enforce checks if there is any change in cache policy file data and get the latst rules from file.

so in this case, we oslo policy find the policy file with overridden rule check_str and consider that instead of rule default value. 

If we change the rule default value in code then policy needs to be initialized again so that new default in code can be loaded.

There is some issue on debug logs because of formatting the target data for logging[1] for this policy but that does not affect on enforce results adding comment about that in glance patch - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/738703/6

[1] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/aa1a5cd62aaa4210b19a5877e77b87db/log/controller/logs/screen-g-api.txt#600

ya i was just not sure if the policy was dynamic and auto reloaded or loaded staticlaly once.

if its dynamic this should be fine unless we see it not working or causing instablitiy.

So far, with the oslo.policy debug turned on, it seems like this happens plenty early and gets reloaded as you would expect. The tempest config happens after this, which hits glance to get image info, which generates API traffic and causes the reload before we need it. And, of course, nova validating image info before the actual boot. So I think this is sufficient and reliable, but I want to leave the policy debug in for that reason for a little while.

It seems cleaner to me to not have to restart glance if we can help it, especially since we're always configuring an apache proxy to standalone glance now, and we don't want to risk tripping a 503 that takes a while to retry or anything.

This happens because of a bug in Glance's object model. It's triggered by a deepcopy of the object before we pass it to the LOG.debug call, which triggers their failure. Ben added this in oslo.policy to try to alleviate it as they decided they don't really need it:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/740068/

But, it's really a lack of a __deepcopy__ handler on the glance side, which I'm probably not signing up to fix for them :)

nova/compute/manager.py.message:
I don't think this check is right.

We can check the shared cpu set pinning range, no the number.
if this is an instance with both pinned and unpinned CPUs, the host must have both 'cpu_dedicated_set' and 'cpu_shared_set' configured
I wonder if it would be sensible to have two checks here with unique messages? This works, but separate messages would be clearer.
Got. If numa_topology is None the code after line L846 will never to executed.
This is an unnecessary check - we know we have 'numa_topology' because of the check on line 831 above

You can drop this. We don't need to say please/thank you in logs [1] :) (yes, we're inconsistent, but the above errors don't use it)

[1] http://www.textdoctor.com/webinars/please/

Thanks, a good document to read!

Done.
nit: would be nice if this was lower case. Maybe in a follow-up? :)

nova/tests/unit/virt/test_hardware.py.message: Can we get a docstring explaining intent?
Sure, Done.

Just copy and paste from somewhere of this file, one example is in #L3843. Looks the naming for this name is inconsistent in this py file, a lot of places used the 'host_topo' and some other places used 'topo_pin'.

How about unifying this object's name in a separate reformating patch.

And I stand for 'host_topo' and 'inst_topo' as the unifying name.
host_topo ?

It's okay if things are a bit different between functions so I wouldn't spend a lot of time on refactoring patches (at least, not until the functional changes merge). We should use the better name in new code

Not critical, but this isn't very realistic. All of the first thread siblings are usually listed first, so 0,4; 1,5; ...

Also, this could fit on one line

Yes. The CPU sibling layout presenting by you is more realistic.

Changed and fixed in one line.
Could you omit this? It's not relevant, right?
It is unrelevant, removed.

[Later]: 

> Could you omit this? It's not relevant, right?

This is required and cannot be omitted. By checking the code, listing as below, in this test, '_numa_pagesize_usage_from_cell' is called, if there is no 'pagesize' is defined in 'InstanceNUMACell', then it will call '_get_smallest_pagesize' for it, the later function thinks 'host_cell.mempages' should be be empty. (my conclusion is from 'return avail_pagesize[0]').

I have to provide one NUMAPagesTopology object for 'host_cell.mempages'.


  def _get_smallest_pagesize(host_cell):
     """Returns the smallest available page size based on hostcell"""
     avail_pagesize = [page.size_kb for page in host_cell.mempages]
     avail_pagesize.sort()
     return avail_pagesize[0]


 def _numa_pagesize_usage_from_cell(host_cell, instance_cell, sign):
     if 'pagesize' in instance_cell and instance_cell.pagesize:
         pagesize = instance_cell.pagesize
     else:
         pagesize = _geot_smallest_pagesize(host_cell)
   ....<Other code>...
Yes, inst_topo is better.
inst_topo ?
Sure. And will make the same dedentation for code blocks found below.

nit: dedent

(below too)
Done and for other tests.

here and elsewhere: you can also state this as

  {4, 5, 6}
There are 4 pinned CPUs on the host
and two pinned CPUs in the guest
Sure. We know the instance NUMA cell and host NUMA cell are matched through a same id.
nit: could you place 'id' at the start? It doesn't matter, but it seems more obvious IMO

...yet we end up with 0 pinned CPUs after freeing the PCPUs used by the instance.

Later: Oh yeah, the isolate policy is in effect here, so the guest is actually consuming four cores (two cores + thread siblings). This needs a comment, for sure :)

As an aside, this won't actually happen in real-life since the 'pin_with_siblings' code is essentially dead code now. We now translate the isolate policy to mean "host must have hyperthreading disabled/no hyperthreading" [1] using a trait reported by the virt driver [2]. The only time we'd trigger the 'pin_with_siblings' code path is on older compute nodes that didn't have both '[compute] cpu_shared_set' and '[compute] cpu_dedicated_set' configured, but you *must* have those configured to use the mixed policy so effectively that's not an option. This test is probably still worth keeping until we remove '(un)pin_with_siblings', but maybe a note that it's going to be going away might be helpful?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/1a154f96f436acad8f4333baa538fede5b11305d/nova/scheduler/utils.py#L289-L297
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/1a154f96f436acad8f4333baa538fede5b11305d/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L10960

Your explanation makes sense to my privious confusion about having the 'isolate' and 'required/prefer' cpu thread policy instances in the hyperthread enabled host.

Since the 'isolate' and 'required' cpu thread policy instances hope to be separated, my confusion solved. 

Understand. And will introduce a note here.
You could make this test clearer by including even more CPUs in the host pinned set. i.e. if there were 6 CPUs pinned, then there should be 2 left after unpinning.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
This job use nova/nova/tests/zero_downtime/hooks/run_tests.sh[1] which i did not find in git history at all when it was added/removed. It is good to remove this broken job and we can write zuulv3 native jobs when we are ready and start testing zero_downtime upgrade. This is only used by nova so removing its definition also once we backport this patch to all the stable branches
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741660/1

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-zuul-jobs/src/commit/18175c771e0678d76cbe28a3d0e5e0f26fac5084/playbooks/legacy/grenade-dsvm-neutron-multinode-zero-downtime/run.yaml#L45

this job depends on x/devstack-plugin-additional-pkg-repos] which is not active[1] and not under OpenStack governance so that we can contact particular project.

- https://review.opendev.org/#/q/project:x/devstack-plugin-additional-pkg-repos

It's good to remove this now and build zuulv3 native job once that plugin is active.

networking_opencontrail/sync/base.py.message: Why do we set these values here instead of passing them within Create/Delete sync methods without setting them as a part of class?

This is actually not a part of this patch, it was just moved up from a child class. Right now it's just how all the synchronizers operate. It can be changed, but as this patch includes some refactoring already, I think it's better if we consider making further modifications in a separate review.

networking_opencontrail/sync/synchronize.message: With this solution we will call multiple times the same Node. We should either add cache for pulling nodes or pull the requested nodes when we have the full list of VPGs to create.
That's true but only for nodes that need more than one VPG to be created for them. I don't think that's a big issue, and trying to solve it would overcomplicate the solution.
is it the only type of error (n_exc.NetworkNotFound ) that can appear here?

I wrote this part to replace manual filtering from all available networks. We expect this error to happen if the network cannot be found. I think it's fine if other, unexpected exceptions are not handled here.
Actually this can happen sometimes when, for example, two syncs are running independently in HA mode. Functionality-wise, this will still work fine and I think such errors in logs can be misguiding.

ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_main.py.message: continue uses the same is_public_api flag as / and /v1 so I'm assuming this much testing is enough

ironic_inspector/utils.py.message: I know it will take a bit longer, but can we make this a flag of BasicAuthMiddleware? Similarly to delay_auth_decision in keystoneauth?

Yes, but I just tested writing the X-Identity-Status header in a custom start_response function, and it happens after the call to check_auth.

This means to support delay_auth_decision in the ironic-lib middleware it will have to be converted to @webob.dec.wsgify, which is fine but will take a bit longer.

So its good that this can land in the meantime :)
We need to do it in the body, not via the status line. str(e) may be too long or even contain new lines. see my ironic-lib patch https://review.opendev.org/#/c/742643/
Doing it this way means the response text has a useful error message instead of the generic http text

lower-constraints.txt.message: this seems dangerous. Can we really go backwards with jsonschema version?

It looks like the previous bump was a mistake as:

  * warlock==1.2.0
   - jsonschema [required: >=0.7,<3, installed: 3.2.0]
  * taskflow==2.16.0
   - jsonschema [required: >=2.6.0,<3.0.0, installed: 3.2.0]
  * python-ironicclient==2.7.0
   - jsonschema [required: >=2.6.0,<3.0.0, installed: 3.2.0]

I think it is safe to go backwards here as lower-constraints is supposed to mark the lower boundary of support right?
Right but this job is running against python 3.6, it can't actually run against 3.8 due to other issues that I'll document in I98da574b6ffd1faf5e673690d8b796e3e09c1bb3 later.
Then we have a bigger problem. As 3.2 was originally forced to support py3.8 https://review.opendev.org/#/c/730960/
Do we need then different lower-constraints per python version?
